awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Physics and Quantum Technology Applications of Defects in Silicon Carbide
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical and computational research on defects in materials that are good candidates to be used for quantum computing. Silicon carbide is a promising material for quantum information processing due to its maturity in industry and compatibility with current electronic device fabrication. Defects refer to disruptions in the perfect regular array of silicon and carbon atoms in a perfect silicon carbide crystal. Promising defects include vacancies such as a silicon atom missing from a site where it is expected or a missing silicon and missing carbon atom on neighboring sites; and the presence of a nitrogen atom along with an associated vacant site. Electrons are confined to quantum mechanical states localized in a small volume. These states can be initialized, manipulated, and measured; they are promising candidates for qubits which are the quantum computer analogs of bits in ordinary computers. Defects in silicon carbide have attractive properties for a range of applications, including quantum-enhanced sensing of electric and magnetic fields, secure quantum communications over long distances, as well as quantum computation. The PIs will develop theoretical tools to understand and exploit the most promising defects in silicon carbide and assess their potential for applications. In particular, the PIs will calculate the dynamics of these defects under interaction with lasers and with static electric fields, using both computational techniques and analytical theory. This work will pave the way toward sensing applications. The properties of the emitted light will also be studied, which will lead to the design of new light-matter interfaces for long-range quantum communication networks. The interactions between the defects and their environment, including the nuclear and vibrational modes, will be calculated, and their effect on the performance of the defect will be assessed. The PIs will also investigate new ways of controlling these quantum systems. The outcomes of this research will contribute toward the development of silicon carbide based systems for powerful future quantum information technologies. This project will also contribute to educating and supporting the next generation of researchers in quantum information science and technology. 


Technical summary

This award supports theoretical and computational research and education to use first principles techniques to investigate the physics and dynamics of defects in silicon carbide, including the process of spin polarization through intersystem crossing and the coupling to electric fields for sensing and spin control applications. A formalism for dynamic nuclear polarization calculations will be developed to understand existing experiments and to reveal the distinct physics of a central spin coupled to two distinct nuclear baths. The viability of silicon carbide devices for quantum communications and repeaters will be assessed. Specifically, this project will characterize spin-photon interfaces for quantum information applications by taking into account mixings of states and couplings to vibrational modes obtained from first principles calculations. Spin control techniques beyond those for qubits will be developed to exploit the silicon vacancy center with S=3/2. The theoretical results of this project will be compared to experimental data and stimulate further experimental studies. This project will also contribute to educating and supporting the next generation of researchers in quantum information science and technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum emitters are critical components of devices on which future quantum networks will be based. To qualify as good candidates for such a role, quantum emitters need to satisfy a range of properties, including having low energy states that can define a qubit, optical transitions at a particular frequency range, stability, and integrability with devices. Emitters in silicon carbide (SiC) appear to satisfy these requirements, but are still not as well understood as their counterparts in diamond. This project focused on modeling of such quantum emitters and on the design of quantum information protocols based on them.  

 

In order to enhance the signal from the defect-based quantum emitters,  it is desirable that these defects be as close to the surface as possible or are placed in a nanostructured host. Using density functional theory-based calculations, we showed how finite-size effects profoundly and often adversely affect properties of near-surface silicon monovacancies in nanostructured SiC. Some of the important findings are: (i) discovery of surface sites that are thermodynamically favorable and which will act as sinks to the quantum emitters, (ii) the strong dependence of the emitter optical properties on the extent of hybridization (i.e., mixing) of the emitter states with the surface states and on the structural changes allowed by proximity to the surfaces, (iii) the possible deterioration of the device performance due to emitters charge-state conversion and/or migration to thermodynamically-favorable under-coordinated surface sites, and (iv) finding possible surface passivation schemes that mitigate the adverse effects of proximity of the monovacancies to the surface. These results have illustrated the importance of considering how finite-size effects affect emitter properties, and the importance of creating mitigating protocols to ensure the charge-state stability of emitters within nanostructured hosts.

 

This project also developed an approach to modeling defects beyond density functional theory, such that multi-electron strong correlations are taken into account. We developed our modeling algorithm using techniques from quantum chemistry and applied it to the well-known NV center in diamond—one of the frontrunners among emitters for quantum network implementation—prior to attempting to model emitters in SiC. This was done because the NV in diamond has been studied for decades, and a vast literature on theoretical/computational and experimental results is available. We found, for the first time, the correct ordering of some important energy levels in the NV center, which were debated in the literature in the past. These levels are important because they play a critical role in the polarization of the qubit in the quantum emitter.

By considering the symmetries of the quantum states, we found additional multi-electron levels that were not considered before. We showed that these additional states are crucial in describing the process in which the Si monovacancy, a SiC emitter consisting of a silicon vacancy (a missing silicon in the lattice) and four neighboring carbons, becomes spin polarized. This is equivalent to initializing the state of the quantum bit, which is the first step of any quantum information processing protocol.

 

This project has also developed protocols for quantum emitters to achieve controlled and precise generation of quantum entanglement, the key property that gives quantum technologies their power. The entanglement between the qubit in the quantum emitter and neighboring qubits in nuclei of certain silicon and carbon isotopes can be controlled with a train of electromagnetic pulses, known as dynamical decoupling sequences. Using concepts that describe the entanglement of one qubit with the rest of the qubits in a system, we have developed an approach to systematically and precisely characterize the types of two-qubit and multi-qubit gates that can be implemented in quantum emitters. While our earlier work focused on the NV center in diamond, which as explained above has been studied extensively, the focus under this project is adapting the technique to SiC emitters. The rich physics in these systems modifies the performance and qualitative behavior of the dynamical decoupling sequences, and is expected to provide additional control and protection of quantum information.

 

The PIs have also been very active with educational and outreach activities. They have created new courses related to the topics of the project and have organized an annual virtual summer school for high school students, where the basics of quantum computing are taught.
